review_title: The bad began to outweigh the good...
job_title: Assistant Director in Bowling Green, KY

job_title: Instructor in Bowling Green, KY
pros: beautiful campus, fun colleges and the IT department is wonderful.  Once our department head changed the moral was better in our department and peoples attitudes changed for the better.
cons: No raises in the 5 years I worked there.  Department head created a divisive atmosphere in the department and played favorites.  Not lots of support for you to continue your education or support for the faculty when student issues happen.  Change of dean in the college brought other issues of concern and the state legislature did not help with the budget.  This has led to poor moral on campus.  Parking is horrible on campus unless you get there at 8am and stay put all day.  You usually have to walk a half mile to your car.  Admin does not support the faculty with daily activities or other duties.  There does not seem to be any transparency in this college.  It seems that others make decisions for your department based on whether they like you or not not based on how our major is reaching the students.  They do not pay very much at all.  We cannot get top talent because the starting pay is so low.  We have had many failed searches due to the pay they were offered.

review_title: Low pay for lots of work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bowling Green, KY
pros: The jobs tend to be very stable. When budgets get hit they tend to just get people who are on optional retirement to retire rather than let people go. Coworkers tend to be friendly and the overall work environment is laid back with just small periods of chaos.
cons:
Widespread nepotism. People tend to be hired from within rather than outside the university even if the outside person is far more qualified. If hired from outside it is usually because they are best friends with someone or related to someone.

While you may not be let go when budget cuts hit, you also will see absolutely no raise. Also often salaries are often not at what they should be for more technical jobs.

job_title: Sales Associate in Bowling Green, KY
pros: It can be a good way to earn experience and determine what sort of businesses you'd like to work in the future. Hours are plentiful during rush as can be expected, but can be pared down to allow a second job at slower times. They work around other jobs and college classes more fairly than most businesses.
cons: Opportunities for promotions are almost non-existent. The pay is low, but fair for retail considering the speed of business and clientele. As different managers are hired and let go, and because the nature of work on a college campus, the culture will change over time. In my case it wasn't to a culture I appreciated initially, but it changed as management changed over time.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Great coworkers that genuinely care about their jobs, each other and the students.
cons: Low pay.  No performance based raises - all political. Lack of leadership. Administration that doesn't care about faculty, staff or students.

review_title: WKU is a great place to work.
job_title: in Bowling Green, KY
pros: The generous sick and vacation time are only the beginning!  Two weeks paid time off at Christmas is counted as holiday pay.  The regular work week is 37.5 hours, and our 'summer' hours are rolled back to 35 hours per week, still getting paid at the regular rate.  Two classes per semester paid for, even if you are not working toward a degree.. but why would you not want to?
cons: As with all employers, there are certain departments or managers who are not as easy to work for. However, it appears that once you're 'in the door' it is fairly simple to transfer to other departments.  I really haven't seen a lot of downsides, and I've been there for over 10 years.

job_title: Education Professor in Bowling Green, KY
pros:
The scenery was pretty, I guess. 
There are always people leaving, so they are usually hiring.
cons:
When I got there, everyone told me what a vengeful and spiteful person he was. Wow, were they right. He loved having me around until he didn't and then I got released without any discussion on how to improve or meet any professional targets. One shot, that's it. My experience there set my career back several years. I regret ever having gone there.

Later, I got to work on a state task force (in a different state) and when people learned that I had been at WKU, they were not surprised. WKU has a reputation for not being able to develop young talent.

review_title: Stable, but limited potential for advancement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bowling Green, KY
pros: The work environment tends to be overall relaxed.  You usually are off for two weeks for Christmas break, which is also nice.  Benefits, while not as good as they were, are still reasonably good.
cons: If your position exists outside of education, expect to get paid roughly 1/2 to 3/ 4 of what you would make in the private sector.  Projects tend to move glacially slow.  There are always funding uncertainties, although it rarely leads to actual elimination of positions, individual budgets tend to shrink a little bit every year.  The importance of your department to the overall University tends to fluctuate depending on the upper level administration and their relationship with the heads of your department/division.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: I learned quite a bit on the job and enjoyed working with many international visitors. I had variation on my day-to-day and was given the freedom to be creative. I had some positive collaborative experiences with other campus departments.
cons: Very political management. I had a bully supervisor; she had no leadership experience and she made the workplace toxic with her temper tantrums, destructive gossip, and constant complaints. I feel sorry for anyone that has to work with her and I'm so glad I only had to work part-time. She drove off several wonderful co-workers. Several trips to the ombudsman and a few complaints were made by various co-workers and the university didn't bother to address my supervisor's behavior.

review_title: I enjoy teaching students as they begin their journey into to the field of nursing, I want to give back to nursing.

pros:
WKU has cutting edge technology and the simulation lab is set up well.
The facility is state of the art and I enjoy the working environment.
cons: I honestly can't think of any cons.  I have attended WKU as a student for three degrees, a graduate teaching asst. and as part time faculty, I am very happy at WKU.

job_title: Information Technology in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Good people to work with.  TONS of free/vacation time. Pretty relaxed and easy-going environment for the most part.
cons: No room to move upwards.  Easy to become complacent and comfortable.  Change comes extremely slowly and the financial instability of the university as a whole has you constantly worrying whether or not your job will be around next fiscal cycle.

job_title: Library Technical Assistant in Bowling Green, KY
pros: My colleague were friendly and for the most part it was low stress.
cons: You'll never see a raise. They will assign you work that is totally unrelated to your position. There were people who had been there for 20 years and were barely paid more than me.

review_title: Great place to start or close out a career
job_title: Communications Specialist in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Western Kentucky University offers a fantastic learning environment for someone who is trying to build up their career early in life. WKU offers student's who are seeking a degree or are recent graduates an environment where there are indeed consequences, but a mistake isn't going to be the end of the world. WKU also feels very much like one large family, so anyone looking for that atmosphere will be very much at home.
cons: WKU, obviously so, very much has that academic atmosphere. For some people, this is exactly what you will be looking for. For others, this will absolutely drive you crazy.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Professors truly care about you and your research. You have great opportunities to work on research that you are passionate about, and also work along side professors who are willing to let you participate in their research projects. You have the opportunity to teach for 2 semesters if you think that is something you would like to do.
cons: Students who write a thesis often take an extra semester to finish it, many times because the deadlines are not communicated clearly.

job_title: in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Nursing has a new building and great sim lab. Parking is easier at the Medical Center campus than on the main campus. In the past we had Lots of funding for things like travel and technology but that is changing  due to state budget cuts. Generally good leadership with faculty input at the program level.
cons: Lower faculty  salary  than our benchmark universities and no raises for years. Class sizes in the undergraduate nursing program are very large.

job_title: Residential Counselor in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Flexibility, travel opportunities, live-in position so you don't have to pay rent, university employee benefits, students and staff are great.
cons: ZERO opportunity for professional development/advancement, the pay sucks, supervisor is pretty laissez-faire most of the year but usually "cracks down" once per month without warning, coworkers are usually young and inexperienced, upper administration are very politically "reactive" instead of proactive to issues within the community, live-in position so you live where you work, your weekly schedule and work days are inconsistent and largely dependent on your coworkers' class schedules, the kids can be needy at all hours of the day/night.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Friendly environment; Great coworkers; Time off over the holiday season; Good benefits, especially in education opportunities; Nice campus; Good work-life balance.
cons: Poor parking; low pay; limited advancement opportunities; highly political; the current administration seems to care little for the student's and staff's wants or needs - they have their own goals; outsourcing all possible positions appears to be the current  trend; few jobs seem safe - other than administration; campus is n very poor financial situation.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Bowling Green, KY
pros:
Having been on-campus for 6 months, and having previously taught at a university in another state, I thought it would be a good time to share my initial observations:
1. Technical support and systems. First-rate support from the IT Department, in every respect. Their use of technology, and the ability to trouble-shoot remotely on those few occasions when I had trouble (always due to my lack of knowledge, not a system error), is just fantastic. The nearly full set of Blackboard tools are available, as well as nearly the full set of BannerWeb (called TopNet here) tools. My college has a full-time IT Tech, located in our building, as well.
2. Interactive video instruction technology - also great. I did a brief training on the system in August, and since then my experience has been flawless. I taught one course this year that had students on-campus and, at the same time, in two remote locations. Technically, the experience was flawless. Facilitators were at the other locations to assist in coordination, and in proctoring of exams.
3. Support for research. While this is not my focus, there appears to be much support for grant identification and application. Also, and despite being a pedagogical professor, I received a good personal allotment for professional development activities this year.
4. Training in instruction. I've taken advantage of several opportunities for education in pedagogical techniques, from both dedicated staff and from panel discussions consisting of peers. Very helpful.
5. Campus. It is a beautiful layout. The academic buildings are all within a few blocks of each other. The architecture is well above-average, and in the most recent decades there has been a greater focus on appearance when constructing new buildings. It has the feel of a smaller campus, despite 20,000 or so students. None of the academic buildings seem more than five stories, and there is plenty of grass and trees, making for some lovely scenery and a relaxed atmosphere.
6. Students. I've been very impressed with the student population, overall. (I'm teaching juniors and seniors, which may skew my opinions somewhat.) And, the major I teach in is fairly difficult (although not the most difficult on campus), which may skew my view. Still, I have been very impressed by the attitudes and attentiveness of the students. Yes, like all students, they need to be motivated; but they respond well to the use of motivational techniques and instruction in personal self-development. Several times this semester, in team projects and in individual assignments, I have been extremely impressed with the students' efforts.
7. Academic advisement. I don't have any academic advisement responsibilities, per se, as our college has dedicated academic advisors. My students report that all six of the academic advisors are great, except one. I still counsel students, of course, but not having to worry about course scheduling has freed me up with more time to spend on career counseling, as well as job and internship outreach and placement.
8. Food. This semester a donor to the campus provided every professor with one free "meal swipe" a week, which will continue for Spring 2016. I typically eat at "Fresh Food" - a cafeteria-like environment serving healthier foods. Other options at the Downing Student Union include Chick Fil A, Lil' John's Pizza, Starbucks, and a burrito place (quite popular with the students). I've tried them all and have been well-pleased. You can purchase "meal swipes" (loaded to your i.d. card) as a professor for under $6 a meal (includes drink). Other food options exist on campus, at various locations. Off campus, Bowling Green is sometimes said to be the "restaurant capital of the world" on a per capita basis, and I have had many pleasurable dining experiences.
9. Parking. I arrive before 8am, and have never had a problem parking in the parking garage nearest my building (only a block's walk away). At times during football games (a couple were held during the week) I had to park in a different lot, which was a couple of blocks further away - but even then had no problem finding a spot. Some professors who go out to lunch return to find a lack of spaces in their preferred faculty lot, but it seems that there are always faculty spaces available in some of the lots, just a bit further away. As is the case with most universities, students encounter some parking difficulties, if they arrive on campus in the late morning; WKU has a plan to build more parking structures.
10. 403(b) Plan. H.R. has done a pretty good job with its 403(b) plan, with TIAA-CREF, Fidelity, and a couple of other custodians as options. It also has a 457 plan for additional deferment opportunities.
11. Health Plan. I came from a state that had one of the best health plans in the country. Here, the plans are unique, in that there is a higher initial out-of-pocket each year. However, you can participate in various wellness programs where the University makes a nice contribution to an HRA and/or an HSA, which in turn limits your out-of-pocket costs. Overall, I'd rate this level of health benefits as a "B" - better by far than most in the commercial business world, but not as great as a few states' health insurance benefits.
12. Collegiality, Mentoring. I'm sure this varies by Department, and by College, but within my department and college I am extremely well pleased. We have a great Dean and Asst. Dean, and they are very supportive, while being common-sense in their decisions, as far as I can see.
13. Development/endowment. Appears to be a substantial endowment, and the President and Deans are raising more in endowment funds each year. Also, various "Centers" exist within each college, and external support for these Centers appears to generally be excellent.
14. Overall, I've been most pleased with my first six months' experience, and with the level of support provided at all levels.
cons:
Hmmm, every place has its "cons" ...
1. Student parking. Always a concern at a larger university. But the number of student complaints is not all that great here. Parking for visitors seems to be available, as well. There is student parking available, always, but it may require parking remotely (at a lot several blocks away, or another larger one at the "South Campus" about 2 miles away) and taking a bus, which could be time-consuming for students. The campus administration appears to be committed to expanding the parking close to campus, through the erection of more parking structures on existing lots near campus. Overall, I would rate this a "C+" - although recognizing that most (if not all) larger universities struggle to keep up with student parking needs.
2. Defined benefit plan. I chose the defined contribution (403b) plan over the defined contribution plan, although I have 6 years to possibly elect to switch over to the defined benefit (pension) plan. The State of Kentucky severely underfunded the Kentucky Teachers pension plan (which includes university professors), and this has created a real budget problem going forward for the State to address. And, like most defined benefit (pension) plans provided by the states, stricter rules now apply as to when vesting occurs and as to how benefits are accumulated; these rules are applicable to newer employees, which makes the defined benefit plan less attractive. I would rate the pension plan as a "D-" at present, due primarily to its underfunding. This situation is not something the University's Administration controls, but is a problem created by the State Legislature.
3. Student retention is above-average for the freshmen year, but only average thereafter, relative to other similar institutions in the state, and nationwide. I'd give the University a grade of "C" on this. It does have a lot of programs and support for students, but from my conversations with students it appears that connecting students to the resources on campus requires more effort.
4. Faculty/staff morale. While it is readily apparent that the professors here are fully supported in terms of their teaching/writing/service activities, the lack of merit increases and relatively low pay increases over the past several years has taken its toll and affected faculty/staff morale, to a degree. While my starting salary was appropriate, in my view, and substantial increases result with promotion, there continues to be uncertainty as to the State Legislature's support of higher education, in general, and faculty/staff salaries, in particular. Great universities emerge when they attract great talent, and without a restoration of CPI and merit pay increases to appropriate levels then WKU will, despite its great progress over the years (from what I have seen and heard), start falling behind. While nearly all state universities have seen reduced state financial support over the past decade, it remains unclear whether the State of Kentucky will get back on track with its support of higher education. I give this one a tentative "D-" ... much depends on the State Legislature's actions in the Spring 2016 session, when they adopt a new 2-year budget. For this reason I rate the "Business Outlook" at "neutral" below, rather than "thumbs up."

review_title: Great University, But As With Most Colleges State Financial Support Poses Challenges for the Future
job_title: Assistant Professor in Bowling Green, KY
pros:
A. Beautiful campus. Relatively compact, as well, providing for relatively easy walking to/from classes and events. (Students complain about "the Hill" - but it's nothing compared to elevation increases seen at many other campuses.) New parking structure will further ease parking pressures on students - which are always present, but no where as severe as they are at most other universities.
B. Diverse but generally pleasant, peaceful campus community. Relatively low crime rate.
C. Nice facilities, in general. Although several academic halls are dated and in need of modernization (this is likely to exist on nearly any college campus). Still, many of the buildings are new or have been recently renovated, and are very pleasant and functional.
D. Great football team. Great tailgating parties.
E. While it may vary from college to college, in general I believe the leadership of the university is top notch. The new President brings forth a new catalyst for changes to occur.
F. A very student-centric focus of the university, generally.
G. A cohesive, student-focused faculty and staff, despite the lack of funding for faculty salary increases over many years. I'm rather surprised that faculty and staff morale and dedication is as high as it is - and this is a credit to the strength of character of Western's faculty and staff.
H. Great IT support, in all respects.
I. Benefits provided to employees remain good. Better than in most states, but not as good as some states. Still, this remains a positive.
cons:
1. The largest concern is, and will be, the decline in state funding. The State of Kentucky, second only (perhaps) to Illinois, has a severe crisis as to the under-funding of its defined benefit plans. Of the total $11-12B state budget, $1.5B now goes to the state pension plan. A recent report indicates that a total of $2.2B is needed, for many years - a $700M increase in funding for the state retirement plans, each year! If the State Legislature addresses this problem (which it must), continued cuts to higher education (and nearly all other parts of the Kentucky State Budget) are inevitable.
    2. This must be put against the backdrop of the lack of substantial faculty/staff pay raises - for many years. While, nationwide, the state support for higher education has rebounded, up 15% or so (and, if you exclude Illinois, up 20% or so) over the past five years, this is not the case in Kentucky. We are down 5.2% in state support over the past 5 years. And, according to the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities (in 2016), Kentucky ranked 6th-worst among states in the percent change to higher education funding per student since 2008. The amount of state funding provided for each student in Kentucky dropped 32 percent, or $2,771, since the recession in 2008 (until the report date).
    3. The effect of this lack of state funding is felt most by students. Higher tuition rates have occurred, although Western Kentucky University still remains quite affordable compared to other universities (both in Kentucky and elsewhere). Housing costs for students, and in general the cost of living, remains low relative to many other college locales. Still, the "funding gap" for students which has occurred (due to the lack of federal increases in the sizes of grants) continues to be exacerbated, as WKU's tuition rates continue to (modestly) increase, and as new student fees are added at times.
    4. As a result of the above, faculty and staff pay is low, relative to other (benchmark) institutions. This has resulted in various inequities (as often exist at universities, as they pay new talent nearly as much as experienced faculty). And it has led to the loss of too many highly qualified applicants, as they receive better offers for employment from competing universities. While a 3% pay increase over 2 years has been provided (after years of none), this has not even kept salaries up with inflation over the two-year period (in all likelihood).
     5. The "easy" budget cuts have likely already been made. Cuts to student services are likely, in the future. As are possible cuts to entire programs, depending on the severity of state under-funding.

review_title: Great benefits. Terrible review and tenure policies
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bowling Green, KY
pros:
This university had so much potential. 

The benefits are decent. Better than other universities I've been at actually. Including retirement
cons:
This university had so much potential. But, if they continue to only hire and promote from their own shallow pool of graduates (called inbreeding in academia). They will never grow or become anything more than a regional university.

Most universities attempt to hire only graduates from other universities as faculty. The keeps ideas flowing, and promotes growth and diversity. The staff in at least one of the colleges of the university is almost entirely made up of WKU graduates who teach things the way they've been taught for 20 plus years. This is no way to lead a progressive educational institution into the future. There are also very few diverse faculty of any type other than Caucasian in this same college. The ones that were of other races or cultures either left or were discriminated against when it comes to tenure and promotion. One, who was a practicing member of the Jewish faith was questioned with a veiled threat of punishment, as to why they needed days off for major Jewish holidays. 

At least in one college that I taught in, the review policy is shoddy and flawed at best. One person reviews you each year. If they don't care for you, or your student reviews are less than stellar (actually they can rationalize anyway they choose since it's only them making the decision) you lose your job. It doesn't matter if this was because they didn't like you for political or personal reasons, overheard detrimental rumors by students in the hallway (this happened to me, and was counted as a negative on my review. Since we all know every student is happy with every teacher everyday without fail. This was a silly and trivial typical unhappy student just venting situation too.), they can just get rid of you. There's no oversight or fair trial. Just a whim.

The benefits are decent. Better than other universities I've been at actually. But the pay was $10k less than any other public institution a colleague and I researched in the nation. That's for the exact same faculty position. You will also be expected to teach a 5/5 load if you are in this college and not tenure. Tenure is 3/3. That's ridiculous, and an overload at most institutions.

To maintain quality faculty, breed diversity, and bring in other methods and skills besides those already taught at the university they need to seriously review and revamp their hiring, dismissal, salary, and other faculty policies.

They also will accept students who score incredibly low on college entrance exams, and then place them into classes way above their level of current ability with few resources to help them. This sets these students up to fail, only to end up with student loans they cannot afford to pay back. It's all about retention at any cost at this school. I have never known another university that will reinstate students who have failed classes, give them a pad on the class they failed, and let them go on, just to keep "numbers up." Is deplorable in so many ways.
